Â Â Â Â Â I built a Flutter mobile app for EMS workers to track their time. As the project grew, the codebase exceeded 5,000 lines, and I realized I needed a way to implement changes without breaking existing functionality. With some free time on my handsâ€”no college classes and no girlfriendâ€”I saw this as an opportunity to deepen my knowledge of Flutter. I set out on a mission to write unit and widget tests for every part of the app.

Â Â Â Â Â One major benefit of writing tests was the chance to refactor and decouple the codebase. For example, one view displaying the history of rescue times was incredibly challenging to write automated tests for because it contained too many widgets within the build function. So, I broke down the 700 lines of widget-heavy code into six smaller widget classes, each focused on specific functionality. This not only made it easier to write widget tests but also made future updates to the code much simpler.

Â Â Â Â Â Another perk of writing comprehensive tests is the confidence it gave me in the appâ€™s functionality. After adding a new column to the database to link records, for example, I knew the databaseâ€™s core functionality remained intact, thanks to the SQLite unit tests Iâ€™d written.

Â Â Â Â Â The biggest downside, however, was the time it took to write all the tests. Each class test took between 30 minutes to two hours, adding up to at least 100 hours of work. Since I had the time, I dedicated about a month and a half to creating these unit and widget tests, all while enjoying a nice latte on Saturday mornings. In the end, it was definitely worth the effort.

Â Â Â Â Â Now, I have an automated testing pipeline that runs whenever I make changes to the codebase. With every commit, GitHub Actions runs the tests, and any failures trigger an email alert, allowing me to quickly address issues. Iâ€™m confident my code changes are safe for release.
